revised_title: Investigating the Heat Required to Kill Bacteria and the Causes of Putrefaction and Fermentation
tldr: The author examines the temperature at which bacteria and their supposed germs are killed when exposed to heat in a moist state and investigates the causes of putrefaction and fermentation. The study reveals that a heat of 140°F (60°C) is often sufficient to kill bacteria, while a higher heat is necessary to prevent putrefaction in organic infusions. The author suggests that the delayed putrefaction may be due to the influence of the non-living organic matter in the inoculating compound.
